title: Financial Controller Roles and Responsibilities
headline: See how top financial controllers can boost productivity with sound financial analysis in this free online course.
description: Determining what constitutes financial controllership can be difficult as it cuts across the lines between precise bookkeeping and leadership. Although accuracy must be ensured, effective financial controllers also need to boost productivity. In this course, you will get the opportunity to discover the specifics of financial control as well as the significance and functions of the controller in boosting an organization's productivity.

courseDescription:
A financial controller is a person in charge of overall accounting and record-keeping for an organization, including managing related staff. They keep track of every expense incurred, records that serve as the fundamental framework of every business and that are essential components of all corporate activity. Financial control is the heartbeat of every organization and inaccurate bookkeeping would create problems when completing tax returns. Therefore, this course has been developed to go over the key duties that the financial controller plays in an organization.

At the beginning, financial control and financial controllers are defined. Then, we will go through how financial control is implemented, the importance of financial controllers, and their main duties. To control an organization’s financial activities, a financial controller must efficiently meet their responsibilities otherwise the organization will not be able to meet its financial obligations. Additionally, the skills a successful financial controller needs to have will be covered. The use of these abilities in business-related financial transactions - such as financial analysis, ratio analysis, budgetary control, strategic management decisions and financial audits - will also be covered in detail.

This course is suitable for both experienced and aspiring financial controllers. By the end, you will have a thorough understanding of financial control and awareness of the main duties and expertise required of financial controllers. This could place you as the guardian of your organization’s financial activities. So, what are you waiting for? Enroll in this course to get started now!

Start Course Now

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module will teach you the concept of financial controller. Then you will learn about the roles and responsibilities of financial controllers in an organisation which include but are not limited to analysis of financial statements, financial analysis, ratio analysis, planning, budgeting and forecasting, and financial audit.

• Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Define financial control and financial controller.
    • Identify different types of financial statements.
    • Discuss comparative financial statement analysis.
    • Explain the advantages of ratio analysis.
    • Classify the ratios and recognise the profitability ratios.
    • Define planning, budgeting, and forecasting.
    • Distinguish functional and master budget.
    • Describe components of internal control.
    • Evaluate value chain analysis.
    • Analyse the types and procedures of financial audits.

  • Lesson Summary

    • Financial control is the heart of organisation's resource management and operational efficiency.
    • A controller is in control of an organisation's accounting and record-keeping.
    • A financial statement is a report that provides an organization's overall financial information and is used to assess a company's financial health and earnings potential.
    • Financial analysis is to analyze a company's financial position and performance.
    • The ratio is the mathematical relationship that exists between any two interconnected variables.
    • Liquidity is the assets that can be converted into cash to pay short-term obligations.
    • Planning sets the framework for a company's financial goals.
    • A budgetary control system is a method of cost planning and control.
    • Budgeting refers to the act of creating budgets.
    • Internal control refers to the organisational plan and measures designed to achieve goals.
    • An internal auditor is a company's employee who conducts audits.
    • Economic value added is the incremental difference in a company's rate of return over its cost of capital.
    • A financial audit evaluates a company's financial statement.
    • Audit risk is the sum of the various risks that may be encountered during the auditing process.
